ITC in Iraq
BEIT Insight Report:
The Sustainability and Reconstruction Meetup
ITC IN IRAQ
About BEIT
The European Union funded,
"Building Equitable and Inclusive
Transformation (BEIT): Towards Decent Work and Affordable Housing in
Iraq" project jointly executed by the International Trade Centre (ITC), UN-
Habitat, and International Labour Organization (ILO) aims to generate
quality jobs by enhancing the housing and construction sector in Iraq.
Under the BEIT project, ITC seeks to contribute to the enhanced
competitiveness and sustainability of local MSMEs in the construction
sector through a more conducive environment, along with increased
inclusive and green trade investment.
Our partnership unites a diverse coalition of leading global construction
and engineering service providers, energy efficiency solution experts,
thought leaders, government agencies, architects, and vocational training
institutions. Together, we are committed to exploring and implementing
affordable, climate-smart solutions that have a tangible, positive impact on
the lives of Iraqi families. This collaboration is grounded in a shared vision
of sustainable development and a dedication to improving living standards
through innovative and practical approaches.
¬© ITC in Iraq
1
ITC IN IRAQ
Executive Summary
On August 21st, 2024, a Sustainability and Reconstruction Meetup was conducted as
part of Iraq's Building Equitable and Inclusive Transformation (BEIT) project. Through
the Sustainability and Reconstruction Meetup people from relevant stakeholder
organizations gathered and shared insights on a sustainability, reconstruction, and
retrofitting training curriculum, setting the stage for further curriculum development
and validation.
Key findings from the mission highlight the potential of various organizations in Mosul
to contribute to the project's goals. The insights gathered emphasize the importance of
integrating local heritage practices with modern sustainability techniques and the need
for innovative training programs that address the challenges of reconstruction and
retrofitting in Mosul.
Digest of Key Points:
Blend traditional architectural elements with modern sustainable practices
Develop sustainability mindsets through innovative, long-term training programs
Address economic challenges, including energy subsidies and upfront costs
Leverage strong community collaboration and volunteer attitudes
Integrate local certification systems (e.g., Green Zugarat Rating System)
Focus on practical, hands-on training and experiential learning
Improve home energy efficiency, especially in water heating
Explore recycling programs for construction waste and batteries
Utilize local academic resources and expertise in sustainable development
Representatives Present From The Following Organizations:
‚Ä¢ Professors from University of Mosul
‚Ä¢ Representatives from the Northern Technical University
‚Ä¢ Engineer from UNESCO
‚Ä¢ Governorate of Nineveh
‚Ä¢ Mosul Space Corporation
‚Ä¢ Riyada for Business
‚Ä¢ Qaf Labs
‚Ä¢ Local engineers and architects
‚Ä¢ Local HVAC professionals
‚Ä¢ Clean.Iraq (SME)
‚Ä¢ Ministry of Electricity
‚Ä¢ Ministry of Environment
‚Ä¢ Mosul Heritage Foundation
‚Ä¢ Other entrepreneurs working in sustainability in Mosul
ITC IN IRAQ
Innovative Training Approaches
Throughout the day various recommendations
for an effective sustainability training curriculum
tailored to the local context were presented.
Participants emphasized the importance of
creating a comprehensive, engaging, and
accessible training program that would impart
technical knowledge and foster a lasting
sustainability mindset among diverse learners.
¬© ITC in Iraq
Recommendations were to keep things simple, community-oriented, and focused on
solving local sustainability problems while saving money. These recommendations aim to
create experiential training beyond traditional classroom settings, leveraging the city and
its heritage as a living laboratory for sustainable practices. The following points outline the
key curriculum recommendations that emerged from the session:
Starting with an awareness campaign before the start of a training program, using
user-generated content (UGC) to foster community participation.
Pre-recorded training modules for a flipped classroom approach.
Pre-selection interviews to select highly motivated participants.
Avoiding paid training programs for participants.
Designing programs that accommodate limited schedule availabilities.
Utilizing experiential and hands-on training methods to increase participant
engagement and learning outcomes.
A focus on mindsets and holistic development was encouraged
Designing the program with a long-term orientation, particularly for developing
mindsets.
Target Diverse Groups: The initiative aims to engage a diverse audience, including
university students and graduates, which could help spread sustainability awareness
across different sectors of society.
Continuous education and awareness: Integration into local processes (ex. Climat
Space at Mosul Space) to build on larger efforts and deepen community engagement
helps with program sustainability.
Design green space excursions as part of the training curriculum to provide hands-on
learning opportunities. Use the ‚Äúcity as a school.
‚Äù
3
ITC IN IRAQ
Sustainable Reconstruction
Capacities Training Outline (draft)
What follows is a draft recommendation outline for a 2-week training leveraging some of
these principles:
Overview of training flow starting with onboarding through an awareness campaign through
social media, and winding up with practical skill development programs. This two week
proposed training will be followed by a quarterly 2 day hackathon and job fair. This will help
connect participants with next-stage opportunities for technical skills training, internships,
and potential future entrepreneurship programs.
¬© ITC in Iraq
4
ITC IN IRAQ
Thematic Overview of Training
Curriculum
Utilizing Dr. Basim‚Äôs Green Zugurat Certification we can identify a general outline of
training domains:
Site sustainability 10%
Water efficiency 28%
Energy efficiency 30%
Materials and resources 12%
Indoor environmental quality 12%
Within these domains, the training will deliver content on the following topics and skills:
Solar systems and energy storage
Insulation materials and sealants - solar radiation and air drafts
Efficient electrical appliances including lighting and ACs
Sustainable Housing Designs
Energy auditing
Solar radiation assessments and heat simulations
Innovation and ideation skills
Rapid prototyping skills
Financial literacy skills
A key insight that emerged from several stakeholders, including professors from Mosul
University, emphasized the need to blend local heritage practices with modern
sustainability techniques. For example, traditional architectural elements that promote
natural cooling can be integrated with contemporary sustainable building methods. This
approach preserves cultural heritage and aligns with modern sustainability goals,
providing a culturally relevant and technically robust framework for the training
curriculum.
¬© ITC in Iraq
5
ITC IN IRAQ
Insights Gathered and Summary
of Whiteboard
The BEIT mission in Mosul provided an opportunity to engage with various stakeholders and
gather diverse insights on sustainable reconstruction and community development. Through
these interactions and discussions, several recurring themes emerged, highlighting key focus
areas for future efforts. These insights underscore the importance of integrating local
heritage with modern sustainability practices, enhancing community engagement, and
addressing training and capacity-building challenges.
ITC IN IRAQ
Challengies
The mission identified several challenges and opportunities in training programs targeting
sustainable reconstruction efforts.
1.
Need for Developing Sustainability Mindsets
Lack of awareness about sustainability challenges locally, developing a
sustainability mindset is crucial.
Focus on experience and practical application over rote learning.
2.
Lack of Alignment With Local Context And International Sustainability Standards
Need to balance heritage preservation with modern engineering solutions.
Importance of finding local standards and solutions.
Developing projects that leverage local materials and skills.
3.
Economic Factors:
Government subsidies make solar panels less attractive for the consumer housing
market and more attractive for government offices and agricultural areas.
Cost-effectiveness concerns due to upfront costs and battery replacements.
Price is a significant factor in adoption.
4.
Technical and Practical Challenges:
Lighting system availability and efficiency in the market; lights create blue light
pollution and are inefficient.
Preventing dust collecting on solar panels as it reduces efficiency.
5.
Energy Subsidy Discussions:
Questions emerged about the cost-effectiveness of solar power within the civilian
housing sector due to subsidies on fuel for generators.
Concerns about the viability of solar power in the market, given the existing
energy subsidies.
6.
Lack of Commitment to Trainings:
Many participants attend training programs primarily for financial incentives rather
than genuine interest, affecting the effectiveness of the training. Ensuring that the
right individuals are targeted and committed to applying what they learn is a
critical challenge.
7.
Questions About The Sustainability of Job Opportunities:
Ensuring that the job opportunities created are sustainable and not just temporary
was a concern.
BEIT, ITC in Iraq
7
ITC IN IRAQ
Opportunities
1.
Adding Momentum To Local Efforts On Heritage Reconstruction:
Highlighting local and traditional practices related to sustainability
Identifying ways that heritage homes are inherently sustainable.
Leveraging Mosul‚Äôs cultural heritage in modern reconstruction can create sustainable
solutions that are both environmentally sound and culturally resonant.
2.
Strong Volunteer and Community Collaboration Between Organizations:
Building collaborative trainings leveraging the strengths of each organization
Engaging the community meaningfully to build local capacity and improve livelihoods
through the project.
3.
Integration of Local Certification Systems into Local Training and Awareness
Programs:
Developing case studies of buildings at different GZRS (Green Zugarat Rating System)
certification levels to enhance local training and awareness.
Integrating local knowledge and practices to create a more contextually relevant
approach to sustainability.
Working with student graduate projects at local universities
4.
Identifying Traditional Sustainability Methods:
To preserve and promote effective indigenous practices, create a catalog of local
innovations in sustainability, including traditional cooling methods.
Support innovative developments of historically inspired sustainable building retrofits
and designs.
BEIT, ITC in Iraq
8
ITC IN IRAQ
Opportunities
5. Community Engagement:
a.
Strong volunteer and contribution attitudes.
b.
Organizations are open to collaboration.
c.
d.
Leverage existing sustainability initiatives (e.g.,
"Climate Space" at Mosul Space).
Developing a battery recycling program to address concerns about imported
batteries.
6. Electrical generation and storage:
Addressing concerns about imported battery quality through a dedicated battery
recycling program.
Explore the feasibility of piezoelectric roads for energy generation.
Identifying electricity costs for different sectors and the subsidies for electrical
generation with gas-powered generators.
7. Improvement in Home Energy Efficiency:
Conduct a detailed study on energy usage in Mosul homes, focusing on heating and
cooling requirements, to identify the most impactful areas for improvement.
A lot of the energy spent in houses is in water heating.
Identify Enhancing water heating efficiency in homes to reduce energy consumption.
8. Leveraging Academic and Local Resources:
Utilizing university projects, the new sustainability department at the University of
Mosul, and local expertise for practical applications in sustainable development.
Emphasize using locally sourced materials and recycling construction and waste rubble
from demolished buildings to promote sustainability and economic resilience.
BEIT, ITC in Iraq
9
ITC IN IRAQ
Community Feedback and
Curriculum Development
During the workshop, a survey was conducted to gather participants' views on the
essential components of a sustainable reconstruction and retrofitting curriculum. The
feedback provided valuable insights into local priorities and areas of interest, which are
summarized below:
Name
What should be included in a sustainability and reconstruction
approach?
Salih Mahmoud Emphasized the importance of design, lighting, and building
philosophy tailored to the city's specific needs.
Bassam Ihsan Abdel Qader
Suggested documenting traditional environmental architectural
elements and incorporating them into the curriculum.
Omar Adel Sabah Highlighted the need for training skilled labor in sustainable
construction methods.
Hanaa Alhasan
Proposed using AI technology in green construction to enhance
sustainability efforts.
BEIT, ITC in Iraq
10
ITC IN IRAQ
Next Steps - Curriculum
Development and Validation
Validation of Curriculum with Stakeholders
When: The last two weeks of October
Action: Organize a curriculum validation session with key stakeholders to
review the proposed curriculum and gather feedback. This session will involve
representatives from the organizations and individuals engaged during the
mission. It can be held in person in Iraq; mid-October could be a good date for
this session.
Purpose: The validation session will ensure that the curriculum is relevant,
practical, and aligned with the goals of the BEIT project. It will also provide an
opportunity to make necessary adjustments before the curriculum is finalized.
Curriculum Co-working session
When: Last two weeks of October
Action: Work with local trainers to co-design and develop the curriculum.
Purpose: To include local knowledge and best practices, to involve potential
future trainers with the material and to finalize the training materials.
Opportunity: Please email me reach out if you would like to be included in the
co-working session and or the curriculum validation.
* Prepared by Bilal Ghalib
